app.name: diff
app.summary: The Diff App compares two different designs at a time. Designs can be any combination of checkpoints or runs. With two designs loaded into memory this App enables the user to compare reports, lists, or first-class object properties between the two designs. The output is generated in the form of interactive reporting (stdout), a text report, or an html report. The app can be used to compare a design against a reference or golden design or to dtermine where divergence occurred (isolation of problems and root cause analysis).

proc.name: activate_design
proc.summary: Activates (makes active) the project and design of the number specified, options are 1 or 2. The project and design are set via set_compare_objects (or open_checkpoints).

proc.name: assert_fail
proc.summary: Ensures that the command fails.

proc.name: assert_false
proc.summary: Compares boolean to false.

proc.name: assert_file_exists
proc.summary: Ensures file exists.

proc.name: assert_pass
proc.summary: Ensures that the command passes. This is normally not needed as a failing command will throw on it's own.

proc.name: assert_same
proc.summary: Compares two values to ensure that they are the same.

proc.name: assert_same_file
proc.summary: Compares files to ensure that they are the same.

proc.name: assert_string_in_file
proc.summary: Ensures string is in file.

proc.name: assert_string_not_in_file
proc.summary: Ensures string is not in file.

proc.name: assert_true
proc.summary: Compares boolean to true.

proc.name: compare_designs
proc.summary:
References the design/project combinations set with set_compare_objects. Then a 'design_command' is executed with each design being made active and the outputs of those commands are captured. Those outputs are then compared using the specified 'difference_command'. The design/project values must have been set with set_compare_objects (or open_checkpoints) before executing this command.
e.g. open_checkpoints design1.dcp design2.dcp; # calls set_compare_objects for us and opens the DCPs compare_designs compare_lines { report_timing -return_string -max_paths 1000 }

proc.name: compare_dirs
proc.summary: Compares directory contents.

proc.name: compare_files
proc.summary: Compares file contents. Similar to the linux diff command. This algorithm is designed to be fast and does not find the best matches between files. For best matching use linux diff or the compare_lines_lcs command, but be aware: the compare_lines_lcs has a long runtime.

proc.name: compare_lines
proc.summary: Compares data by lines, and looks for the closest next line match when it encounters a difference.

proc.name: compare_objects
proc.summary: Compare first-class Tcl object properties.

proc.name: compare_ordered_lists
proc.summary: Compare ordered lists and finds in-order differences. Uniqueness is not considered in this algorithm.

proc.name: compare_serialized_objects
proc.summary: Compare serialized object properties. To serialize objects use the command serialize_objects. To read in objects that have been serialized to disk use serialize_from_file.

proc.name: compare_unordered_lists
proc.summary: Compare unordered lists and finds unique objects that exist in each list/set.

proc.name: get_checkpoints
proc.summary: Gets checkpoints to be used for design comparisons.

proc.name: get_compare_objects
proc.summary: Gets design and project objects to be used for design comparisons.

proc.name: get_global_report
proc.summary: Gets global report value. The output of this command is what resource will be used to output data if unique resources are not provided to the print_* commands. Use set_global_report to change.

proc.name: get_verbose
proc.summary: Gets verbosity mode.

proc.name: html_escape
open_checkpoints
proc.summary: Opens checkpoints while capturing the corresponding design and project objects. Channel is not specified here, and cannot be used with the design comparison flow. Use the set_global_report for controlling the outputs channel with design comparisons.

proc.name: print_alert
proc.summary: Print an alert message. For HTML reports this shows in dark red.

proc.name: print_css
proc.summary: Return Cascaded Stylesheet (CSS) information for HTML report

proc.name: print_end
proc.summary: Print end of the report. If using an HTML report, then this prints the ending HTML tags.

proc.name: print_header
proc.summary: Print a heading. For HTML reports this begins the different sections of the report.

proc.name: print_info
proc.summary: Print a info message. For HTML reports this shows in dark blue.

proc.name: print_js
proc.summary: Return JavaScript (JS) information for HTML report

proc.name: print_msg
proc.summary: Print generic message. Most print_* commands use this as the base proc for reporting.

proc.name: print_results
proc.summary: Print a result message. For HTML reports this shows in dark gray.

proc.name: print_stamp
proc.summary: Print current time stamp, current build, current changelist, and process ID.

proc.name: print_start
proc.summary: Print report title, if using HTML, then this generates the head content of the HTML report.

proc.name: print_subheader
proc.summary: Print a sub-heading. For HTML reports this begins the pre-formatted area under each heading.

proc.name: print_success
proc.summary: Print a success message. For HTML reports this shows in dark green.

proc.name: remove_comments
proc.summary: Removes all comments

proc.name: remove_datestamps
proc.summary: Removes all date stamps

proc.name: remove_special
proc.summary: Removes all special characters, except '-', '_', and whitespace

proc.name: remove_whitespace
proc.summary: Removes all whitespace

proc.name: serialize_from_file
proc.summary: Read data from file. Can be used as a generic file reader.

proc.name: serialize_objects
proc.summary: Serializes all provided first-class Tcl objects.

proc.name: serialize_to_file
proc.summary: Writes data to file. Can be used as a generic file writer, but this command always appends.

proc.name: set_checkpoints
proc.summary: Sets checkpoints to be used for design comparisons.

proc.name: set_compare_objects
proc.summary: Sets design and project objects to be used for design comparisons.

proc.name: set_global_report
proc.summary: Sets global report file name and can be set to stdout or stderr. If not specified, then each print_* command requires a file name be provided to the channel argument. If the file name has the extension 'htm' or 'html', then an HTML report will be generated.

proc.name: set_verbose
proc.summary: Sets verbosity mode. True or 1 will print verbose, false or 0 will not.

proc.name: unique_in_both_sets
proc.summary: Find the unique items in set1 and in set2. Also known as the 'Symmetric Difference' or (A\B) U (B\A) [ ( $set1 \ $set2 ) U ( $set2 \ $set1 ) ].

proc.name: unique_in_first_set
proc.summary: Find the unique items in set1. Also known as the 'Set Difference' or U\A [ $set1 \ $set2 ].
